In today's issue we publish a letter
from one of the students at the University advocating a much milder
form of the Honor System than that
which has been approved by the
Honor System Committee.
We venture to suggest that if the
Honor System is to exist here at all,
it must exist without misunderstanding, that two main features of that
System are necessary, though to the
highest degree unpleasant—(I) The
reporting of a suspected student by
his fellow-student. (2) The strictest punishment for those who are
found guilty—that if the University
is not willing to accept and uphold
these two conditions, it is better not
to attempt to institute the system.

THE

HUXLEY

SOCIETY

New Society Formed at the University for the Discussion of
Philosophical Problems.
A number of members of the faculty and graduate students have
formed an organization for the discussion of general philosophical
problems under the name of the
Huxley Society. This name has been
adopted both because of Huxley's
early connection with the Johns
Hopkins University, and because
Huxley's general attitude towards
philosophical problems is that which
must be taken by a society composed
of biologists, philosophers, literary
men and representatives of the natural and social sciences. The Huxley Society of course does not commit itself to Huxley's specific philosophic doctrines, or to those of any
other individual or school.
One of the purposes of the society
is to bring to the Johns Hopkins for
public lectures philosophic thinkers
who would not otherwise be heard
here, and who will present the most
recent and important contributions
to the solution of the fundamental
problems of science and philosophy.
The lecturer selected for this term
is Prof. W. P. Montague, of the
Department of Philosophy of Columbia University, and head of the
Department of Philosophy and Psychology of Barnard College. , Dr.
Montague will speak on "Life and
Mind as Forms of Energy," on Friday, the first of April, at eight
o'clock, in Levering Hall, all those
interested being invited to attend.
Dr. Montague is one of the two
philosophers who have done the
most work in the development of
what is called New Realism; a
philosophy based on the principles
and discoveries of natural science,
and thouroughly in harmony with
the latter.
This development has
been a protest against both the
German Idealism and the older Materialism, both of which broke down
in the attempt to relate the phenomena of life and mind with those
of the inorganic world. The New
Realism agrees with Pragmatism in
that it finds consciousness to be a
biological function, but it advances
beyond the pragmatic position in
that it finds consciousness and physical phenomena to be parts of one
intelligible
scheme, thus
doing
away with the gap between brain
process and
consciousness, and
with the conflict between vitalism
and mechanism in biology.
As the lecture by Dr. Montague
is open to all who are interested in
fundamental problems, he will present his subject with as great freedom from philosophical technicalities as is consistent with the purpose
of the lecture.

early connection with the Johns
Hopkins University, and because
Huxley's general attitude towards
philosophical problems is that which
must be taken by a society composed
of biologists, philosophers, literary
men and representatives of the natural and social sciences. The Huxley Society of course does not commit itself to Huxley's specific philosophic doctrines, or to those of any
other individual or school.
One of the purposes of the society
is to bring to the Johns Hopkins for
public lectures philosophic thinkers
who would not otherwise be heard
here, and who will present the most
recent and important contributions
to the solution of the fundamental
problems of science and philosophy.
The lecturer selected for this term
is Prof. W. P. Montague, of the
Department of Philosophy of Columbia University, and head of the
Department of Philosophy and Psychology of Barnard College. , Dr.
Montague will speak on "Life and
Mind as Forms of Energy," on Friday, the first of April, at eight
o'clock, in Levering Hall, all those
interested being invited to attend.
Dr. Montague is one of the two
philosophers who have done the
most work in the development of
what is called New Realism; a
philosophy based on the principles
and discoveries of natural science,
and thouroughly in harmony with
the latter.
This development has
been a protest against both the
German Idealism and the older Materialism, both of which broke down
in the attempt to relate the phenomena of life and mind with those
of the inorganic world. The New
Realism agrees with Pragmatism in
that it finds consciousness to be a
biological function, but it advances
beyond the pragmatic position in
that it finds consciousness and physical phenomena to be parts of one
intelligible
scheme, thus
doing
away with the gap between brain
process and
consciousness, and
with the conflict between vitalism
and mechanism in biology.
As the lecture by Dr. Montague
is open to all who are interested in
fundamental problems, he will present his subject with as great freedom from philosophical technicalities as is consistent with the purpose
of the lecture.
